Hi Michael,

Michael Gillam wrote:

> ...but I am glad to see that an amazingly active group of
>programmers have independently created their own torch and are leading the
>way into this Great Frontier.  Ironically, a striking example of convergent
>cognitive evolution, if I ever saw one!
>  
>
It's certainly been a very active group just recently and I've found it 
very interesting and useful to have a group of like minded folks 
bouncing ideas around.

>
> [stuff about genome encodings]

Well I actually started out by devising an indirect encoding based on a 
genome with a tree structure. What I realised was, that without 
something to compare against I couldn't determine if the technique was 
better than the more simple direct encodings out there. So anyway, I 
came to the conclusion that it would be a good idea to explore the 
limits of direct encodings before moving on to the rather daunting task 
of devising and researching indirect encodings. I've read the 'Taxonomy 
for Artificial Embryogeny' paper and definitely recommend you have a 
look at it, I agree that indirect encodings are a very intersting area 
of research and that they represent what is probably THE single most 
interesting (and challenging) problem in AI research today.

Actually, I don't know how others feel about this but I'm sometimes 
slightly baffled at just how underdevelped this areas of AI research is 
and that some of this work wasn't done years ago!

Regards,

Colin.
